bibl.title: Monthly Progress Report from Lunsford D. Fricks to the Surgeon General, March 5, 1924

div1.p: Fricks reports on malaria investigations conducted in the southern United States.

div1.head: Monthly Progress Report from Lunsford D. Fricks to the Surgeon General, March 5, 1924
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
FIELD HEADQUARTERS
ROOM 17, COURTHOUSE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS, TENN.
March 5, 1924.
FB
COPY
Monthly Progress Report,
-----February 1924-----
The Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Division of Scientific Research,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to forward herewith monthly progress re-
port of malaria investigations conducted during the month of
February, 1924, under the direction of this office:

Field Laboratory, Crowley, La.: Personnel - Special Expert
M. A. Barber, Asst. San. Eng. W. H. W. Komp and Asst. San. Eng.
J. G. Foster.

Activities at the Crowley Laboratory consisted of: (1) Prepa-
ration of reports and papers for publication; (2) Observations
on winter incidence of Anopheles, Anopheles collected thirteen,
of which eleven were A. quadrimaculatus and two A. crucians,
twelve females and one male (A. crucians); larvae and pupae col-
lected and bred out one hundred and thirty-two, of which one
hundred and twenty-five were A. crucians and seven A. quadrimacu-
latus; (3) Sixty-six blood specimens examined for malaria para-
sites, nine positive, two P. vivax and seven P. falc.; four of
these positives were positive last year.

Memphis Laboratory: Personnel - A. A. Surgeon Wm. A. Krauss,
Microscopists Ethel Barrier and Retha Kitchens.

Six hundred and thirty-three smears were examined for malaria
parasites; sixty-six collected locally showed four positives;
one hundred and six from Greenwood, Miss., showed thirteen posi-
tives; four hundred and sixty-one from Gulfport, Miss., showed
thirty positives, of the sixty-seven positives sixty were
P. falc., six P. vivax and one P. falc and P. vivax.
Monthly Progress Report
March 5, 1924.

Field Laboratory, Savannah, Ga.: Personnel - Technical Assistant
Bruce Mayne.

Study of winter activities of Anopheles continued: Findings a-
bout the same as previously reported; apparently Anopheles pass
the winter largely in the aquatic stages in this locality; what
appeared to be two-day larvae of A. crucians were observed; ex-
cept around midday larvae were collected in greatest numbers from
bottom mud; no male Anopheles observed; no adult Anopheles found;
one hundred and twenty-eight blood smears examined, one positive.

Epidemiological Studies of Malaria: Personnel - Asst. Surgeon
K. F. Maxcy.

Compilation of data collected last year regarding malaria preva-
lence in Alabama; three maps were prepared showing location of
malaria based on positive slides, based on physicians' reports
and based on malaria deaths; analysis made of two hundred and
seven death certificates attributed to malaria, cause of death
doubtful in 50% of cases.

Impounded Waters in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Epidemiolo-
gist T. H. D. Griffitts and Asst. San. Eng. E. H. Gage.

No impounded water studies conducted by Dr. Griffitts during Feb-
ruary. No observations reported.

Mr. Gage reports finding Anopheles larvae and pupae in many ponds
and seepage pools of Aiken County, South Carolina, full grown
larvae and pupae predominating, occasionally small larvae were
found; all emergences A. crucians, 58% of which were males. No
adult Anopheles found until February 28th, when one female puncti-
pennis was found in a hollow tree.

Major Drainage in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Assoc. San.
Eng. A. W. Fuchs.

Data collected in McKinney Lake District in Tunica County, Miss.,
analyzed and summarized. Hibernation observations made February
21 and 22, freezing temperature at night, in Crittenden County,
Ark., and Tunica County, Miss.; one A. punctipennis and one
A. quadrimaculatus caught under bridges, three A. quadrimaculatus
in one house and three in one barn. Study was made of tempera-
ture and humidity records in relation to malaria distribution.
Monthly Progress Report
March 5, 1924.

Rural Malaria Investigations: Personnel - Asst. San. Eng. J. C.
Carter, A. A. Surgeon C. P. Coogle, Assoc. San. Eng. L. M. Fisher,
Asst. San. Eng. H. N. Old, Asst. San. Eng. F. R. Shaw, and
Surgeon L. L. Williams, Jr.

Mr. Carter (Alabama) conferred with county health officers of
Houston, Barbour and Covington Counties relative to malaria con-
trol program for 1924, and with county health officials of Dothan
and Eufaula. Made survey of drainage project in Autauga County;
collected nineteen adult Anopheles in Houston County, five A.
crucians, fourteen A. punctipennis (female); collected three adult
A. punctipennis (female) in Covington County February 27th.

Mr. Old (Georgia) assisted Dr. Coogle in malaria school surveys;
one thousand three hundred and sixty-four Chatham County school
children examined, less than one-half one one per cent enlarged
spleens found, thorough inspection made of borrow pits along the
A. C. L. Railway; malaria spot map of county being prepared;
establishment of a full-time county health department recommended
by the Frand Jury.

Mr. Shaw (Louisiana) reports: Program of urban and rural malaria
control in Tangipahoa Parish outlined to parish health officer
and local officials; study of winter habits of Anopheles contin-
ued, many Anopheles larvae but no pupae collected; a screen cage
was erected over a lumber pile at Hammond in an effort to col-
lect hibernating adults, none found during several days observa-
tions.

Mr. Fisher (South Carolina): Studies of malaria prevalence in
eighteen counties continued; seventy-five thousand school census
cards sent out; study of winter habits of Anopheles continued;
on February 15th eight adult Anopheles, six A. quadrimaculatus
and two A. punctipennis collected from Crystal Lake and Adams
Pond; on February 28th, three A. punctipennis and two A. quadri-
maculatus collected at Adams Pond; on February 14th, two larvae
and one pupae collected near Georgetown.

Surgeon L. L. Williams (Virginia): Detached from Virginia and
temporarily assigned to duty in South Carolina.

Dr. C. P. Coogle continued malaria school surveys in Georgia and
South Carolina; thirty-four schools visited during the month;
one thousand five hundred and thirty-four children examined for
enlarged spleens; one thousand four hundred and fifty-five
Monthly Progress Report
- 4 -
March 5, 1924.
blood smears made and sent to Memphis Laboratory for examination.
Dr. Coogle observed many adult crucians, males and females, in
Charleston and Georgetown Counties, South Carolina, approximate-
ly two hundred were observed under one bridge and many were
found in barns and under house porches.

Conferences and Inspections: Senior Sanitary Engineer J. A.
LePrince delivered two lectures to the classes of the Medical
Department of the University of Tennessee during the month;
attended conference of the New Jersey Mosquito Extermination
Association February 13-16th.

Medical Officer in Charge delivered a series of lectures on in-
sect-borne diseases in the United States to classes of the
Medical Department of the University of Tennessee; delivered
two lectures to classes at the University of Georgia Medical
School at Augusta, Georgia, on malaria and other insect-borne
diseases in the United States February 20-21st; conferred
with Dr. Farmer, County Health Officer of Aiken County, South
Carolina, relative 1924 malaria program February 21; conferred
with Dr. Coogle, Mr. Old, Mr. Mayne and local health authori-
ties of Chatham County, Georgia, and inspected activities in
the County, February 22; conferred with State Health Officer
of Alabama and malaria field force in Montgomery, Alabama, Feb-
ruary 23rd.

Expenditures: During the month approximately $3,128.40 was
expended from the Malaria Allotment in connection with field
investigations of malaria.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge.
